metadata.title: USMLE Step 1 Question Bank: Congenital Heart Disease - Part 3
metadata.description: Questions 17-32: Williams, DiGeorge, HCM, VSD, PPHN, Eisenmenger, AVSD, TAPVR, Truncus, Tricuspid Atresia, Ebstein, ALCAPA, and HLHS

questions.title: Williams Syndrome - 7q11.23 Deletion
questions.subject: Genetics
questions.vignette: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for evaluation of developmental delay. His parents describe him as 'extremely friendly' and talkative, with an unusual affinity for music and strangers. Physical examination shows a small, upturned nose; long philtrum; full lips and cheeks; and a wide mouth ('elfin' facies). He has a systolic murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border. Blood pressure is normal. Serum calcium is mildly elevated.
questions.questionText: Which of the following chromosomal abnormalities is most likely responsible for this child's condition?

answerChoices.text: 5p deletion (Cri-du-chat syndrome)
7q11.23 microdeletion involving the elastin gene
11p15 imprinting defect (Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome)
15q11-13 paternal deletion (Prader–Willi syndrome)
22q11 deletion (DiGeorge syndrome)

explanation.correct: This child has Williams syndrome, caused by microdeletion of chromosome 7q11.23 including the elastin (ELN) gene. Key features include: Cardiac abnormalities (supravalvular aortic stenosis, peripheral pulmonary stenosis due to loss of elastin → connective tissue abnormality), Facial features ('elfin' facies with broad forehead, short nose, full cheeks/lips, wide mouth), Personality (extremely social, outgoing, 'cocktail party personality'; affinity for music), Metabolic findings (hypercalcemia in infancy from ↑ vitamin D sensitivity), and Cognitive features (mild-moderate intellectual disability, but strong expressive language).

incorrect.A: 5p deletion (Cri-du-chat) presents with 'cat-like' cry, microcephaly, wide-spaced eyes; different phenotype.
incorrect.C: 11p15 imprinting (Beckwith-Wiedemann) presents with macroglossia, organomegaly, omphalocele, Wilms tumor risk; not cardiac/facial pattern here.
incorrect.D: 15q11-13 paternal deletion (Prader-Willi) presents with hypotonia, hyperphagia, obesity, short stature; different features.
incorrect.E: 22q11 deletion (DiGeorge) presents with conotruncal heart defects, thymic hypoplasia, hypocalcemia (opposite), cleft palate; not this pattern.

questions.educationalObjective: Williams syndrome results from a microdeletion on chromosome 7q11.23 including the elastin (ELN) gene. Loss of elastin causes supravalvular aortic stenosis. Patients have 'elfin' facial features, an outgoing personality, strong verbal skills, and often hypercalcemia.
keyFacts: 7q11.23 deletion (includes ELN gene)
Supravalvular AS, peripheral PS
'Elfin' facies + friendly personality
Hypercalcemia (infancy)
Strong language, love of music

questions.title: 22q11 Deletion (DiGeorge) - Truncus Arteriosus
questions.subject: Genetics
questions.vignette: A term neonate presents on day 2 of life with cyanosis and poor perfusion. Physical examination shows a single loud S2 and a harsh ejection systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border. Chest radiograph reveals an absent thymic shadow. Serum calcium is 6.5 mg/dL (low). Echocardiography demonstrates a persistent truncus arteriosus with a VSD.
questions.questionText: Which of the following genetic conditions best explains these findings?

answerChoices.text: 22q11.2 deletion
Autosomal trisomy
Fibrillin mutation
Frataxin mutation
Hamartin gene mutation
Sex chromosome monosomy

explanation.correct: This neonate has 22q11.2 deletion syndrome (DiGeorge), characterized by: Cardiac abnormalities (conotruncal anomalies including truncus arteriosus, TOF, interrupted aortic arch), Thymic aplasia/hypoplasia → T-cell immunodeficiency (absent thymic shadow), Parathyroid aplasia → hypocalcemia, and other features (cleft palate, learning disabilities). The embryologic mechanism involves failed development of 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches (neural crest defect). CATCH-22 mnemonic: Cardiac abnormalities (conotruncal), Abnormal facies, Thymic aplasia, Cleft palate, Hypocalcemia, 22 = chromosome 22.

incorrect.B: Trisomy 21 is strongly linked to AVSD, not truncus arteriosus.
incorrect.C: Fibrillin (Marfan) causes aortic root disease in adolescents/young adults, not neonatal conotruncal lesions.
incorrect.D: Frataxin (Friedreich ataxia) causes hypertrophic cardiomyopathy; neurologic disease appears later.
incorrect.E: Hamartin (TSC1, tuberous sclerosis) causes rhabdomyomas, seizures, cortical tubers; not conotruncal with thymic/parathyroid aplasia.
incorrect.F: Turner (45,X) causes coarctation and bicuspid aortic valve; occurs in females.

questions.educationalObjective: 22q11.2 deletion syndrome (DiGeorge) causes conotruncal anomalies (truncus arteriosus, TOF), thymic aplasia (absent thymic shadow), and hypocalcemia from parathyroid aplasia due to failed development of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches.
keyFacts: CATCH-22 mnemonic
Conotruncal defects (truncus, TOF, IAA)
Hypocalcemia (parathyroid aplasia)
Absent thymus → recurrent infections
Facial: hypertelorism, low-set ears, micrognathia

questions.title: Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy - Murmur Maneuvers
questions.subject: Physiology
questions.vignette: A 24-year-old man with exertional dyspnea is diagnosed with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). On auscultation, a harsh systolic murmur is heard best at the left lower sternal border.
questions.questionText: Which maneuver will decrease the intensity of this murmur?

answerChoices.text: Sudden standing (from squatting to standing)
Straining phase of Valsalva maneuver
Squatting from standing position
Administration of nitroglycerin
Inspiration

explanation.correct: HCM murmur physiology: Obstruction varies inversely with LV volume. Smaller LV → more septal–mitral leaflet contact → louder murmur. Larger LV → less contact → softer murmur. Squatting: ↑ preload AND ↑ afterload → ↑ LV end-diastolic volume → murmur softens. This is the 'rebel murmur' that behaves opposite to most other cardiac murmurs.

incorrect.A: Standing causes ↓ preload → smaller LV → increases murmur.
incorrect.B: Valsalva (strain) causes ↓ preload → smaller LV → increases murmur.
incorrect.D: Nitroglycerin causes ↓ preload/afterload → smaller LV → increases murmur.
incorrect.E: Inspiration primarily augments right-sided flow; minimal effect on left-sided HCM murmur.

questions.educationalObjective: In HCM, maneuvers that increase LV volume (e.g., squatting; ↑ preload/afterload) decrease murmur intensity, whereas maneuvers that decrease LV volume (standing, Valsalva, nitrates) increase it.
keyFacts: HCM = 'rebel murmur' (behaves opposite to most)
Make LV big → murmur quiet
↑ LV volume: squat, handgrip, leg raise → softer
↓ LV volume: stand, Valsalva, nitrates → louder
Contrast with AS, MR, VSD (all get softer with ↓ preload)

questions.title: VSD - Handgrip Effect
questions.subject: Physiology
questions.vignette: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic for a routine sports physical. He has no medical complaints. On cardiac examination, a harsh holosystolic murmur is heard best at the left lower sternal border and is palpable as a thrill. The murmur becomes louder with sustained handgrip exercise and softer when the patient performs a Valsalva maneuver. Lung fields are clear.
questions.questionText: Which of the following is the most likely cardiac lesion in this patient?

answerChoices.text: Aortic stenosis
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
Small ventricular septal defect
Mitral valve prolapse
Pulmonary stenosis

explanation.correct: The combination of a harsh holosystolic murmur at LLSB with palpable thrill and louder with handgrip strongly suggests VSD. Handgrip physiology: ↑ systemic vascular resistance (afterload) → ↑ left-ventricular and aortic pressures → ↑ L→R pressure gradient across VSD → Murmur louder. Valsalva (strain): ↓ preload → ↓ LV volume → ↓ shunt flow → Murmur softer. Small (restrictive) VSDs produce loud, harsh murmurs with thrill, large L→R gradient (high velocity), and are usually asymptomatic ('Maladie de Roger'). Large (nonrestrictive) VSDs produce softer murmurs (equalized pressures) but cause heart failure symptoms.

incorrect.A: Aortic stenosis produces crescendo–decrescendo systolic murmur at RUSB, radiates to carotids; decreases with handgrip.
incorrect.B: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy produces midsystolic murmur that decreases with handgrip and increases with standing/Valsalva.
incorrect.D: Mitral valve prolapse produces late systolic murmur with click that moves earlier when LV volume falls (standing/Valsalva).
incorrect.E: Pulmonary stenosis produces systolic ejection murmur at LUSB that increases with inspiration, not handgrip.

questions.educationalObjective: Handgrip exercise increases afterload, intensifying murmurs of left-to-right shunts (VSD) and regurgitant lesions (MR, AR), while reducing the intensity of outflow-tract murmurs (AS, HCM). Small VSDs are typically loud and asymptomatic; large VSDs produce heart-failure findings and a softer murmur.
keyFacts: Handgrip: ↑ afterload → louder VSD, MR, AR
Handgrip: ↓ HCM, AS
Small VSD: loud murmur, asymptomatic
Large VSD: soft murmur, CHF
Most VSDs close spontaneously

questions.title: Persistent Pulmonary Hypertension - Differential Cyanosis
questions.subject: Physiology
questions.vignette: A term newborn develops cyanosis several hours after birth. The infant was delivered via uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal delivery. While changing the diaper, the father notices the legs appear bluish, but the hands and face are pink. Pulse oximetry results: Right hand (preductal): 98%, Left foot (postductal): 83%. The infant exhibits grunting respirations and subcostal retractions. Cardiac auscultation reveals a soft holosystolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. Femoral pulses are strong and symmetric.
questions.questionText: Which of the following best explains this patient's cyanosis?

answerChoices.text: Failure of pulmonary vascular resistance to decrease after birth, leading to right-to-left flow through the ductus arteriosus
Increased left atrial pressure causing right-to-left shunting across a patent foramen ovale
Obstruction of blood flow distal to the left subclavian artery reducing lower-extremity oxygenation
Increased left-to-right shunting through a patent ductus arteriosus, leading to pulmonary overcirculation
Reduced systemic vascular resistance causing reversal of flow through an atrial communication

explanation.correct: This infant has differential cyanosis (pink upper body, blue lower body) indicating right-to-left shunting across the PDA, distal to the left subclavian artery. Normal transition: Birth → ↑ O₂ → pulmonary vasodilation → PVR ↓, PVR < SVR → L→R ductal flow → closure. PPHN (Persistent Pulmonary Hypertension of Newborn): PVR remains elevated, PA pressure > aortic pressure, R→L shunt through PDA, deoxygenated blood enters descending aorta, lower-extremity cyanosis. Key findings: Differential cyanosis (hands pink, feet blue), Preductal > Postductal SaO₂ (>5-10% difference), Strong femoral pulses (excludes coarctation), Holosystolic murmur = tricuspid regurgitation (from pulmonary HTN).

incorrect.B: ↑ LA pressure → R→L PFO would be an intracardiac shunt that would desaturate both upper and lower body (no differential).
incorrect.C: Coarctation would cause weak femorals, not strong ones.
incorrect.D: L→R PDA shunt causes pulmonary overcirculation, not cyanosis.
incorrect.E: Low SVR → R→L atrial shunt would cause equal cyanosis in all extremities.

questions.educationalObjective: Differential cyanosis (pink hands, blue feet) indicates right-to-left flow from the aorta into the pulmonary artery with mixing across a PDA—a classic finding in persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN). Failure of pulmonary vascular resistance to decrease after birth causes right-to-left shunting across the patent ductus arteriosus and produces differential cyanosis.
keyFacts: Differential cyanosis = R→L PDA shunt (PPHN)
Preductal > postductal SaO₂
Strong femorals (vs. coarctation)
Treatment: 100% O₂, inhaled NO, ECMO if refractory
Reversed differential (blue hands, pink feet) = TGA + PDA

questions.title: Oxygen Saturation Step-Up - ASD
questions.subject: Cardiology
questions.vignette: Cardiac catheterization is performed on a school-age child for evaluation of a murmur. Oxygen saturations are: SVC 70%, IVC 70%, RA 81%, RV 81%, PA 81%, LA 96%, LV 96%, Aorta 96%.
questions.questionText: Which of the following findings is most likely on physical examination?

answerChoices.text: Continuous, machinery-like murmur at the left infraclavicular area
Fixed splitting of S2
Holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border
Bifid carotid pulse with brisk upstroke
Early diastolic decrescendo murmur at the left sternal border

explanation.correct: Oxygen saturation step-up analysis: Step-up first appears in RA (70% → 81%), RA, RV, and PA all similarly elevated (81%), Pattern = left-to-right shunt at atrial level (ASD). ASD physiology: L→R shunt → ↑ RA/RV volume, ↑ flow across pulmonic valve, Persistent delay in P2 closure, Fixed wide split S2 (pathognomonic). Why 'fixed'? RA pressure equalized with LA throughout respiratory cycle, RV volume overload constant, P2 delay does not vary with respiration.

incorrect.A: Continuous murmur indicates PDA (step-up at PA level, not RA).
incorrect.C: Holosystolic murmur LLSB indicates VSD (step-up at RV level, not RA).
incorrect.D: Bifid carotid pulse indicates HCM or AR; not a shunt lesion.
incorrect.E: Early diastolic murmur indicates aortic or pulmonary regurgitation; not a shunt.

questions.educationalObjective: A step-up in O₂ saturation from SVC/IVC to RA localizes a left-to-right shunt to the atrial level (ASD) and classically causes wide, fixed S2 splitting.
keyFacts: Step-up location determines shunt level: RA = ASD, RV = VSD, PA = PDA
Fixed split S2 = pathognomonic for ASD
Flow murmur at LUSB (pulmonic valve)
May have mid-diastolic rumble (tricuspid flow)

questions.title: Coarctation of the Aorta - Classic Presentation
questions.subject: Cardiology
questions.vignette: A 16-year-old boy is referred to cardiology after a school sports physical reveals elevated blood pressure. He denies chest pain, dyspnea, or syncope and is an active soccer player. Vital signs show blood pressure of 158/88 mm Hg in the right arm and 102/70 mm Hg in the right leg. Physical examination reveals well-developed upper body musculature with relatively smaller lower extremities. Cardiac auscultation demonstrates a systolic ejection murmur at the left sternal border and between the scapulae posteriorly. Femoral pulses are weak and delayed compared with the brachial pulses. Chest radiograph shows rib notching.
questions.questionText: Which of the following embryologic abnormalities best explains this patient's condition?

answerChoices.text: Failure of the ductus arteriosus to close after birth
Abnormal development of left fourth aortic arch and left dorsal aorta
Anterior malalignment of the infundibular septum
Failure of neural crest cell migration affecting the aorticopulmonary septum
Excessive resorption of septum primum during atrial septation

explanation.correct: This patient has coarctation of the aorta, indicated by: Upper extremity hypertension with lower extremity hypotension, Arm-leg blood pressure differential (>20 mm Hg), Weak, delayed femoral pulses (brachial-femoral delay), Systolic murmur in back (turbulent flow through narrowed aorta), Rib notching on CXR (from collateral circulation via intercostal arteries). Coarctation is a discrete narrowing of the aorta, typically just distal to the left subclavian artery at the site of the ligamentum arteriosum (postductal type in adolescents/adults). Embryology: Develops from the left fourth aortic arch and left dorsal aorta, Abnormal development → localized narrowing, Most common site: juxtaductal (near ligamentum arteriosum).

incorrect.A: PDA failure to close creates continuous murmur, wide pulse pressure, bounding pulses (not weak femorals); no arm-leg BP differential.
incorrect.C: Anterior malalignment of infundibular septum causes Tetralogy of Fallot, not aortic narrowing.
incorrect.D: Neural crest failure (AP septum) causes truncus arteriosus or TGA, not isolated aortic narrowing.
incorrect.E: Septum primum resorption causes ASD (ostium secundum), not aortic coarctation.

questions.educationalObjective: Coarctation of the aorta results from abnormal development of the aortic arch (left fourth arch and dorsal aorta), causing discrete narrowing typically distal to the left subclavian artery. Classic findings include upper extremity hypertension, weak delayed femoral pulses, arm-leg BP differential, and rib notching from collateral flow through intercostal arteries.
keyFacts: Location: Just distal to left subclavian (juxtaductal)
Classic triad: ↑ upper extremity BP, ↓ lower extremity BP, weak delayed femorals
CXR findings: '3 sign' (indentation), rib notching (>5 years old)
Associations: Turner syndrome (15%), bicuspid aortic valve (50-85%), berry aneurysms
Complications: LV hypertrophy, CHF, aortic rupture, endocarditis, stroke
Treatment: Surgical repair or balloon angioplasty

questions.title: Coarctation - Infantile Presentation
questions.subject: Cardiology
questions.vignette: A 3-week-old male infant is brought to the emergency department for poor feeding and lethargy over the past 2 days. He was born at term without complications but has had difficulty gaining weight. Vital signs show temperature 36.8°C (98.2°F), heart rate 180/min, respiratory rate 68/min, and blood pressure 65/40 mm Hg in the right arm. Physical examination reveals a pale, mottled infant in respiratory distress with weak pulses in all four extremities. Liver edge is palpable 3 cm below the costal margin. A gallop rhythm is present but no significant murmur is heard. When prostaglandin E₁ infusion is started, the infant's perfusion dramatically improves and lower extremity pulses become palpable.
questions.questionText: Which of the following mechanisms best explains the improvement after prostaglandin E₁ administration?

answerChoices.text: Decreased pulmonary vascular resistance improving pulmonary blood flow
Restoration of systemic perfusion to the lower body via patent ductus arteriosus
Increased myocardial contractility improving cardiac output
Decreased systemic vascular resistance reducing left ventricular afterload
Closure of left-to-right shunt reducing pulmonary overcirculation

explanation.correct: This infant has severe (critical) coarctation of the aorta presenting as ductal-dependent systemic circulation. Key findings: Acute decompensation at 2-3 weeks (as ductus closes), Poor perfusion, weak pulses in all extremities initially, Hepatomegaly and gallop (CHF), Dramatic improvement with PGE₁. Preductal (infantile) coarctation: Severe narrowing proximal to or at the ductus arteriosus, Lower body perfusion depends on PDA, As ductus closes → acute CHF, shock, metabolic acidosis, Upper body may also be poorly perfused due to low cardiac output. PGE₁ mechanism: Keeps ductus arteriosus open, Blood from pulmonary artery → descending aorta via PDA, Restores perfusion distal to coarctation, Allows stabilization before surgical repair.

incorrect.A: ↓ PVR improving pulmonary flow - Problem is systemic, not pulmonary; pulmonary flow is adequate.
incorrect.C: Increased contractility - PGE₁ is not an inotrope; improvement is from opening ductus, not cardiac effect.
incorrect.D: ↓ SVR reducing afterload - PGE₁ primarily affects ductal smooth muscle; SVR changes are minimal and not the primary mechanism.
incorrect.E: Closure of L→R shunt - PGE₁ opens the ductus, not closes it; there is no L→R shunt to close in coarctation.

questions.educationalObjective: Critical (severe preductal) coarctation of the aorta presents in the first 2 weeks of life as the ductus arteriosus closes. Lower body perfusion depends on right-to-left flow through the PDA. Prostaglandin E₁ maintains ductal patency, restoring systemic perfusion distal to the obstruction until surgical repair.
keyFacts: Preductal coarctation = ductal-dependent systemic circulation
Presents when ductus closes (days 7-14)
Findings: shock, weak pulses (all extremities), CHF, acidosis
Differential diagnosis: Sepsis, cardiomyopathy, HLHS
Treatment: PGE₁ → stabilize → surgical repair
Associated with: Turner syndrome, bicuspid aortic valve

questions.title: Eisenmenger Syndrome - Pathophysiology
questions.subject: Pathophysiology
questions.vignette: A 28-year-old woman presents to the cardiology clinic with progressive dyspnea and fatigue over the past year. She was diagnosed with a large ventricular septal defect in childhood but her family could not afford surgery. Physical examination reveals central cyanosis, digital clubbing, and a prominent right ventricular heave. A loud P2 is heard, but the previously documented holosystolic murmur is no longer present. Chest radiograph shows enlarged central pulmonary arteries with peripheral pruning. Echocardiography demonstrates severe pulmonary hypertension with bidirectional shunting across the VSD.
questions.questionText: Which of the following pathophysiologic processes best explains the change in this patient's murmur?

answerChoices.text: Spontaneous closure of the ventricular septal defect
Development of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction
Reversal of shunt direction due to elevated pulmonary vascular resistance
Progressive left ventricular systolic dysfunction
Development of tricuspid regurgitation masking the VSD murmur

explanation.correct: This patient has Eisenmenger syndrome, the irreversible pulmonary arterial hypertension that develops from long-standing left-to-right shunts. Initially, the large VSD caused a left-to-right shunt with high pulmonary blood flow, producing a holosystolic murmur. Years of excessive pulmonary flow caused progressive pulmonary vascular remodeling with medial hypertrophy, intimal proliferation, and ultimately plexiform lesions. As pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) increases and eventually exceeds systemic vascular resistance (SVR), the shunt reverses to right-to-left. With equalized pressures across the VSD, there is no longer a pressure gradient to produce a murmur—hence the disappearance of the holosystolic murmur. The loud P2 reflects pulmonary hypertension. Central cyanosis and clubbing result from deoxygenated blood bypassing the lungs via the right-to-left shunt. This condition is inoperable because the pulmonary vascular disease is fixed.

incorrect.A: Spontaneous VSD closure - While small VSDs can close spontaneously, large VSDs (which cause Eisenmenger syndrome) rarely close. Moreover, if the VSD closed, the patient would not have bidirectional shunting on echo and would likely have worsening right heart failure from pure pulmonary hypertension without a pop-off mechanism.
incorrect.B: RVOT obstruction - This would create a new murmur (systolic ejection murmur), not eliminate the existing VSD murmur. RVOT obstruction is characteristic of Tetralogy of Fallot, not Eisenmenger syndrome.
incorrect.D: LV dysfunction - Would cause symptoms of heart failure but wouldn't eliminate the VSD murmur. In fact, LV dysfunction might reduce shunt volume but a pressure gradient would still exist if the shunt were left-to-right.
incorrect.E: TR masking VSD murmur - Tricuspid regurgitation does commonly develop with pulmonary hypertension, but it creates its own holosystolic murmur (different location and characteristics), rather than masking the VSD murmur.

questions.educationalObjective: Eisenmenger syndrome occurs when long-standing left-to-right shunts cause irreversible pulmonary vascular disease. As pulmonary vascular resistance exceeds systemic resistance, the shunt reverses to right-to-left. The previously audible murmur disappears as pressures equalize across the defect, and patients develop cyanosis and clubbing from chronic hypoxemia.
keyFacts: Eisenmenger = irreversible pulmonary arterial hypertension from chronic L→R shunt
Pathophysiology: Excessive pulmonary flow → vascular remodeling → PVR > SVR
Shunt reversal: L→R becomes R→L when PVR exceeds SVR
Murmur disappears: No pressure gradient = no murmur
Physical exam: Cyanosis, clubbing, loud P2, loss of original murmur
Inoperable: Fixed pulmonary vascular disease
Complications: Hemoptysis, paradoxical emboli, arrhythmias, sudden death
Treatment: Supportive care, pulmonary vasodilators, transplant only option

questions.title: Complete AVSD - Down Syndrome Association
questions.subject: Genetics/Pathology
questions.vignette: A 2-month-old infant with trisomy 21 is brought to the pediatrician for poor feeding and tachypnea. The parents report the infant sweats profusely during feeds and takes frequent breaks. Physical examination reveals tachypnea, a hyperdynamic precordium, and a holosystolic murmur heard best at the lower left sternal border with radiation to the axilla. The liver edge is palpable 3 cm below the right costal margin. Chest radiograph shows cardiomegaly with increased pulmonary vascular markings. Echocardiography demonstrates a large primum atrial septal defect, inlet ventricular septal defect, and a common atrioventricular valve.
questions.questionText: Which of the following embryologic abnormalities best explains this infant's cardiac defect?

answerChoices.text: Failure of neural crest cell migration
Incomplete fusion of endocardial cushions
Abnormal septation of the truncus arteriosus
Premature closure of the foramen ovale
Persistence of the ostium secundum

explanation.correct: This infant has complete atrioventricular septal defect (AVSD), also called endocardial cushion defect or atrioventricular canal defect, which is the most common cardiac anomaly in Down syndrome (40-45% of cardiac defects in trisomy 21). Complete AVSD results from failure of the superior and inferior endocardial cushions to fuse during weeks 4-5 of embryonic development. These cushions normally fuse to form the lower portion of the atrial septum (septum primum), the upper portion of the ventricular septum, and separate the mitral and tricuspid valves. When fusion fails, the result is: (1) primum ASD (lower atrial septum defect), (2) inlet VSD (upper ventricular septum defect), and (3) a common AV valve with a characteristic 'cleft' in the anterior mitral leaflet. The large left-to-right shunt causes excessive pulmonary blood flow, leading to congestive heart failure (tachypnea, hepatomegaly, poor feeding). The holosystolic murmur represents either the VSD or AV valve regurgitation (or both).

incorrect.A: Neural crest cell failure - Neural crest cells contribute to conotruncal development and aortic arch formation. Defects in neural crest migration cause conotruncal abnormalities (truncus arteriosus, transposition, tetralogy of Fallot) and aortic arch anomalies (interrupted aortic arch, coarctation). Neural crest cells are not involved in endocardial cushion or AV valve formation.
incorrect.C: Truncus septation abnormality - Abnormal septation of the truncus arteriosus produces conotruncal defects such as persistent truncus arteriosus, transposition of great arteries, or tetralogy of Fallot. These are characterized by abnormal great vessel relationships, not AV valve or septal defects at the crux of the heart.
incorrect.D: Premature foramen ovale closure - The foramen ovale normally remains patent throughout fetal life and closes functionally at birth (and anatomically over months to years). Premature closure would cause fetal hydrops and stillbirth, not the cardiac anatomy seen here. This doesn't create AVSDs.
incorrect.E: Persistent ostium secundum - Persistent ostium secundum creates a secundum ASD (central atrial septal defect), not the primum ASD seen in AVSD. Secundum ASDs result from excessive resorption of septum primum or inadequate growth of septum secundum, completely separate from endocardial cushion development. Secundum ASDs don't involve the AV valves or ventricular septum.

questions.educationalObjective: Complete atrioventricular septal defect (AVSD) results from failure of endocardial cushion fusion, creating a primum ASD, inlet VSD, and common AV valve. AVSD is the most common cardiac defect in Down syndrome and presents with congestive heart failure from excessive pulmonary blood flow.
keyFacts: AVSD = endocardial cushion defect, most common CHD in Down syndrome
Embryology: Failure of superior + inferior endocardial cushion fusion (weeks 4-5)
Anatomy: Primum ASD + inlet VSD + common AV valve (5 leaflets total)
Physiology: Large L→R shunt → pulmonary overcirculation → CHF
Presentation: Poor feeding, tachypnea, failure to thrive, hepatomegaly
Physical exam: Hyperdynamic precordium, holosystolic murmur, fixed split S2
CXR: Cardiomegaly, increased pulmonary vascular markings
Types: Partial AVSD (primum ASD + cleft mitral) vs Complete AVSD
Associated with: Down syndrome (40-45%), heterotaxy syndromes
Management: Early surgical repair (3-6 months) to prevent Eisenmenger

questions.title: Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Return - Obstructed
questions.subject: Pathology/Physiology
questions.vignette: A term newborn develops severe respiratory distress and cyanosis within hours of birth. The infant is lethargic with poor perfusion. Physical examination reveals tachypnea, grunting, retractions, and central cyanosis. Oxygen saturation is 65% despite 100% inspired oxygen. A loud single S2 is heard, but no murmur is audible. The liver is not enlarged. Chest radiograph shows a normal-sized heart with diffuse ground-glass opacities and prominent interstitial markings. Initial assessment suggests severe persistent pulmonary hypertension, but echocardiography reveals all four pulmonary veins draining into a vertical vein posterior to the left atrium, which descends and enters a hepatic vein below the diaphragm.
questions.questionText: Which of the following best explains this infant's severe presentation in the first hours of life?

answerChoices.text: Mixing at the atrial level through a restrictive foramen ovale
Pulmonary venous obstruction from compression of the vertical vein
Decreased pulmonary blood flow from right ventricular hypoplasia
Severe left ventricular outflow tract obstruction
Parallel circulation with inadequate ductal mixing

explanation.correct: This infant has infracardiac (type 3) total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR) with obstruction—the most critical variant of TAPVR requiring emergency surgery. In TAPVR, all four pulmonary veins fail to connect to the left atrium and instead drain anomalously into the systemic venous system. In the infracardiac type, a vertical vein descends through the diaphragm to join the portal venous system or ductus venosus. This pathway is inherently restrictive because: (1) the vertical vein traverses the diaphragm and can be compressed during breathing, (2) the hepatic sinusoids offer high resistance, and (3) mixing with deoxygenated blood occurs before reaching the heart. Obstruction causes severe pulmonary venous congestion with pulmonary edema (ground-glass appearance on CXR mimicking respiratory distress syndrome), pulmonary hypertension, and right heart failure. The infant presents with severe cyanosis unresponsive to oxygen because blood cannot adequately return from the lungs. The normal heart size distinguishes this from typical CHF (which causes cardiomegaly). This is a surgical emergency—delayed diagnosis is fatal.

incorrect.A: Restrictive foramen ovale - While TAPVR requires an ASD for survival (oxygenated blood must reach the left heart somehow), a restrictive foramen ovale would cause right heart failure and cyanosis but not the severe pulmonary edema seen here. The severity and presentation (immediate after birth, diffuse pulmonary edema) point to pulmonary venous obstruction, not inadequate atrial mixing.
incorrect.C: RV hypoplasia - Right ventricular hypoplasia is not a feature of TAPVR. The right ventricle receives increased preload in TAPVR (all pulmonary and systemic venous return), leading to RV dilation, not hypoplasia. The presentation here is from venous obstruction, not inadequate RV output.
incorrect.D: LVOT obstruction - TAPVR doesn't involve left ventricular outflow obstruction. The left ventricle is typically small due to reduced preload (since pulmonary veins don't connect to LA), but there's no anatomic LVOT obstruction. This wouldn't explain the pulmonary edema pattern.
incorrect.E: Parallel circulation - This describes transposition of great arteries (TGA), where aorta and pulmonary artery arise from opposite ventricles. TGA presents with cyanosis but typically NOT with pulmonary edema or respiratory distress, and it has a different chest X-ray appearance (egg-on-string silhouette, not ground-glass opacities).

questions.educationalObjective: Obstructed total anomalous pulmonary venous return (especially infracardiac type) presents in the first hours of life with severe cyanosis and respiratory distress from pulmonary venous congestion. The chest radiograph shows pulmonary edema with a normal-sized heart, mimicking severe lung disease. This is a surgical emergency.
keyFacts: TAPVR = all pulmonary veins drain to systemic venous system (not LA)
Types: Supracardiac (to SVC/innominate), cardiac (to RA/coronary sinus), infracardiac (below diaphragm), mixed
Infracardiac = most likely to be obstructed = surgical emergency
Obstruction → severe pulmonary venous congestion → pulmonary edema + PH
Presentation: Immediate cyanosis, respiratory distress, shock, pulmonary edema
CXR: Normal heart size + ground-glass/interstitial markings (mimics RDS or PPHN)
Diagnosis: Echo shows anomalous venous connection, no veins entering LA
Requires ASD for survival (systemic blood reaches LV through atrial shunt)
Treatment: Emergency surgical repair (reconnect veins to LA)
Differential: PPHN, RDS, obstructed TAPVR—echo differentiates

questions.title: Truncus Arteriosus - Presentation
questions.subject: Pathology/Physiology
questions.vignette: A 3-week-old infant is brought to the pediatrician for poor feeding and rapid breathing. The infant was born at term without complications. Over the past week, the parents have noticed increasing difficulty with feeding, with the infant becoming tired and sweaty during feeds. Physical examination reveals tachypnea, a hyperdynamic precordium, and a harsh systolic murmur heard at the left sternal border. A loud single S2 is noted. The infant has mild cyanosis of the lips. Chest radiograph shows cardiomegaly with increased pulmonary vascular markings. Echocardiography demonstrates a single large arterial trunk arising from the heart, giving rise to the aorta, pulmonary arteries, and coronary arteries, with a large ventricular septal defect directly beneath the truncal valve.
questions.questionText: Which of the following hemodynamic abnormalities best explains this infant's clinical presentation?

answerChoices.text: Decreased pulmonary blood flow from severe pulmonary stenosis
Parallel circulations with minimal mixing
Excessive pulmonary blood flow from low pulmonary vascular resistance
Complete mixing with balanced systemic and pulmonary blood flow
Pulmonary venous obstruction with pulmonary edema

explanation.correct: This infant has persistent truncus arteriosus, a conotruncal defect where failure of the truncus arteriosus to divide results in a single great vessel supplying the systemic, pulmonary, and coronary circulations. The truncal valve overrides a large VSD, and the pulmonary arteries arise directly from the common trunk. The hemodynamic consequence is torrential pulmonary blood flow because: (1) the pulmonary arteries receive blood directly from the high-pressure truncus (systemic-level pressure), (2) as pulmonary vascular resistance naturally drops in the first weeks of life, pulmonary blood flow increases dramatically, and (3) there is obligate complete mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood in the common trunk. The result is pulmonary overcirculation with congestive heart failure (tachypnea, poor feeding, sweating, hepatomegaly) plus mild cyanosis from mixing. The single S2 reflects the single truncal valve. Without surgery in infancy, these patients develop Eisenmenger syndrome rapidly due to early irreversible pulmonary vascular disease from chronic high-flow, high-pressure pulmonary circulation.

incorrect.A: Decreased pulmonary flow - The opposite is true. Truncus arteriosus is characterized by EXCESSIVE pulmonary blood flow because the pulmonary arteries receive blood at systemic pressure directly from the trunk. This patient has CHF from pulmonary overcirculation, not cyanosis from reduced pulmonary flow.
incorrect.B: Parallel circulations - This describes transposition of great arteries (TGA), where the aorta and pulmonary artery arise from opposite ventricles, creating two separate circuits that must mix at the atrial or ductal level. Truncus arteriosus has a single vessel supplying both circulations—complete mixing occurs at the truncal level, not parallel circuits.
incorrect.D: Balanced flow - While there is complete mixing in truncus arteriosus, the flow is NOT balanced. The low PVR in early infancy causes preferential flow to the lungs, resulting in pulmonary overcirculation and systemic underperfusion. The presentation (CHF, not severe cyanosis) confirms excessive rather than balanced pulmonary flow.
incorrect.E: Pulmonary venous obstruction - This occurs in conditions like obstructed TAPVR or cor triatriatum, where pulmonary venous return is impeded, causing pulmonary edema and respiratory distress. Truncus arteriosus has normal pulmonary venous drainage to the left atrium—the problem is arterial (excessive flow TO the lungs), not venous (obstruction FROM the lungs).

questions.educationalObjective: Persistent truncus arteriosus results in torrential pulmonary blood flow once PVR drops after birth, causing congestive heart failure with mild cyanosis. The single arterial trunk supplies both systemic and pulmonary circulations at systemic pressure, leading to pulmonary overcirculation and early development of pulmonary vascular disease if not surgically corrected.
keyFacts: Truncus arteriosus = single arterial trunk supplying systemic + pulmonary + coronary circulations
Embryology: Failure of truncus arteriosus and conus to divide (weeks 5-6)
Anatomy: Large VSD, single truncal valve, pulmonary arteries arise from trunk
Types: Type I (short main PA from trunk), Type II (separate branch PAs), Type III (PAs from aorta—actually interrupted aortic arch with PDA)
Hemodynamics: Complete mixing + torrential pulmonary flow → CHF + mild cyanosis
Presentation: CHF at 2-4 weeks (as PVR drops): poor feeding, tachypnea, failure to thrive
Physical exam: Single loud S2, systolic murmur, hyperdynamic precordium, ± diastolic murmur (truncal valve regurgitation)
Associated findings: Truncal valve abnormalities (stenosis/regurgitation), 22q11.2 deletion (DiGeorge)
Natural history: Early Eisenmenger syndrome (by 1-2 years) if untreated
Treatment: Surgical repair in first weeks/months of life (VSD closure + RV-to-PA conduit)

questions.title: Tricuspid Atresia - Pathophysiology
questions.subject: Pathology/Physiology
questions.vignette: A term newborn develops progressive cyanosis over the first 24 hours of life. The infant appears comfortable at rest but becomes more cyanotic with crying. Physical examination reveals central cyanosis, tachypnea, and a single S2. A soft systolic murmur is heard at the left sternal border, but no diastolic murmur is present. Oxygen saturation is 70% and does not improve significantly with supplemental oxygen. Chest radiograph shows decreased pulmonary vascular markings and a boot-shaped cardiac silhouette. Echocardiography demonstrates absence of the tricuspid valve with no flow from the right atrium to the right ventricle, along with an atrial septal defect and ventricular septal defect.
questions.questionText: Which of the following pathways is essential for this infant's survival?

answerChoices.text: Right-to-left shunting at the atrial level
Patent ductus arteriosus providing pulmonary blood flow
Left-to-right shunting through the ventricular septal defect
Anomalous pulmonary venous return to the right atrium
Coronary arterial fistula to the right ventricle

explanation.correct: This infant has tricuspid atresia, a cyanotic congenital heart disease characterized by complete absence of the tricuspid valve and no connection between the right atrium and right ventricle. For survival, blood must follow an alternative pathway: (1) systemic venous return enters the RA but cannot reach the RV, so it MUST cross an ASD (right-to-left) to reach the left atrium, (2) blood then enters the LV where it mixes with pulmonary venous return, (3) from the LV, blood must reach the pulmonary circulation somehow—this occurs through LEFT-TO-RIGHT flow across a VSD into the hypoplastic RV, and then to the pulmonary artery. The VSD is the critical pathway allowing blood to reach the lungs. If the VSD is too small (restrictive), pulmonary blood flow is inadequate, causing severe cyanosis. The patient may also require a PDA to supplement pulmonary blood flow, but the VSD is the primary route. Without a VSD (or an alternative communication), no blood would reach the lungs and the infant would not survive. The physiology requires obligate mixing at the atrial level (for survival) and obligate L→R flow at the ventricular level (for oxygenation).

incorrect.A: R→L shunting at atrial level - While right-to-left shunting across the ASD is NECESSARY (systemic venous return must reach the left side) to survive, it is not SUFFICIENT. The ASD allows survival but doesn't explain how blood gets to the lungs. The complete answer requires both the ASD (for systemic return to reach the left side) AND the VSD (for blood to reach the pulmonary circulation). Choice C is more complete.
incorrect.B: PDA for pulmonary flow - The PDA does provide additional pulmonary blood flow in some cases of tricuspid atresia and may be essential if the VSD is restrictive or if there's associated pulmonary stenosis. However, the PRIMARY route for pulmonary blood flow in tricuspid atresia is through the VSD (L→R shunt from LV to hypoplastic RV to PA). The PDA is supplementary, not the main pathway.
incorrect.D: Anomalous pulmonary venous return - This is not a feature of tricuspid atresia. Pulmonary veins drain normally to the left atrium. Anomalous pulmonary venous connection describes different lesions (TAPVR, partial APVR) where veins drain to the right-sided circulation—not present here.
incorrect.E: Coronary fistula to RV - Coronary arterial fistulas are rare anomalies where coronary arteries connect abnormally to cardiac chambers or vessels. This is not a feature of tricuspid atresia and would not provide a pathway for pulmonary blood flow. This is a distractor.

questions.educationalObjective: Tricuspid atresia requires obligate right-to-left shunting at the atrial level (for systemic venous return to reach the left heart) and left-to-right shunting through a VSD (for blood to reach the lungs via the hypoplastic RV). Survival depends on adequate communication at both levels.
keyFacts: Tricuspid atresia = absent tricuspid valve, no RA→RV connection
Obligate pathways: ASD (R→L) for survival + VSD (L→R) for pulmonary blood flow
Blood flow: Systemic venous return → RA → ASD → LA → LV → (VSD) → hypoplastic RV → PA
Complete mixing in LA → cyanosis inevitable
Pulmonary blood flow depends on VSD size ± PDA
RV and PA are hypoplastic (reduced flow during development)
Presentation: Cyanosis (severe if VSD restrictive), ± CHF if unrestricted VSD
CXR: Decreased pulmonary markings (restrictive VSD) OR increased markings (large VSD)
Single ventricle physiology requiring staged palliation
Treatment: Stage 1 (Blalock-Taussig shunt or PDA stent in neonatal period), Stage 2 (Glenn at 4-6 months), Stage 3 (Fontan at 2-4 years)

questions.title: Ebstein Anomaly - Tricuspid Valve Malformation
questions.subject: Pathology
questions.vignette: A 16-year-old girl presents to the cardiology clinic for evaluation of exercise intolerance and palpitations. She reports becoming short of breath with mild exertion and occasionally feels her heart racing. She has a history of 'a heart murmur' since infancy but has not had regular cardiology follow-up. Physical examination reveals mild cyanosis of the lips and a prominent jugular venous pulsation with a prominent V wave. Cardiac auscultation reveals a widely split S1 with a soft, holosystolic murmur at the lower left sternal border that increases with inspiration. Chest radiograph shows massive cardiomegaly with a 'box-shaped' heart. Electrocardiogram demonstrates a right bundle branch block pattern and tall, peaked P waves in lead II.
questions.questionText: Echocardiography in this patient would most likely show which of the following findings?

answerChoices.text: Anterior displacement of the posterior leaflet of the mitral valve
Apical displacement of the septal leaflet of the tricuspid valve
Bicuspid aortic valve with fusion of the right and left coronary cusps
Myxomatous degeneration with prolapse of the anterior mitral leaflet
Thickening and fusion of the tricuspid valve leaflets with doming during diastole

explanation.correct: This patient has Ebstein anomaly, a congenital malformation of the tricuspid valve characterized by apical displacement (downward movement) of the septal and posterior leaflets of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle. The anterior leaflet is typically elongated and 'sail-like'. This displacement creates an 'atrialized' portion of the RV (the part of the RV above the displaced valve functions as part of the RA), resulting in: (1) a very enlarged right atrium (causing massive cardiomegaly and 'box-shaped' heart on CXR), (2) tricuspid regurgitation (holosystolic murmur that increases with inspiration), (3) reduced functional RV size, (4) predisposition to atrial arrhythmias (palpitations) and right-to-left shunting via patent foramen ovale or ASD (causing cyanosis). The widely split S1 is pathognomonic—it results from delayed closure of the elongated, displaced tricuspid valve compared to the mitral valve. Ebstein anomaly has a wide spectrum of severity from asymptomatic to severe heart failure/cyanosis in infancy. It is associated with maternal lithium use during pregnancy and with Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (accessory pathway, causing palpitations).

incorrect.A: Anterior displacement of posterior mitral leaflet - This describes mitral valve prolapse (MVP), specifically of the posterior leaflet. MVP would cause a mid-systolic click followed by a late systolic murmur, not a holosystolic murmur. It wouldn't explain the massive RA enlargement, cyanosis, or the constellation of findings pointing to a right-sided lesion.
incorrect.C: Bicuspid aortic valve - A congenital aortic valve anomaly that may be asymptomatic or cause aortic stenosis/regurgitation. Would produce a systolic ejection murmur at the right upper sternal border (not left lower sternal border) and wouldn't cause cyanosis, massive cardiomegaly, or right atrial abnormalities. This is a left-sided lesion.
incorrect.D: Myxomatous mitral valve prolapse - Mitral valve prolapse from myxomatous degeneration produces a mid-systolic click and late systolic murmur (as the valve prolapses back into the LA during systole). The murmur would radiate to the axilla, not be heard at the LLSB with inspiration increase. MVP doesn't cause cyanosis or the characteristic ECG/CXR findings seen here.
incorrect.E: Tricuspid stenosis - Thickening and fusion of tricuspid leaflets describes rheumatic tricuspid stenosis, which is extremely rare (almost always occurs with mitral stenosis). Tricuspid stenosis produces a diastolic rumble at the LLSB, not a holosystolic murmur. It also doesn't cause the massive cardiomegaly or congenital presentation seen here. Ebstein is a malformation, not stenosis.

questions.educationalObjective: Ebstein anomaly is characterized by apical displacement of the septal and posterior tricuspid valve leaflets into the right ventricle, creating an atrialized RV and enlarged RA. The widely split S1 (delayed tricuspid closure) is pathognomonic. Patients present with tricuspid regurgitation, arrhythmias, and cyanosis from right-to-left shunting.
keyFacts: Ebstein anomaly = apical displacement of septal + posterior tricuspid leaflets
Pathognomonic finding: Widely split S1 (delayed tricuspid closure)
Anatomy: Atrialized RV + massive RA + elongated 'sail-like' anterior leaflet
Hemodynamics: Severe TR + reduced functional RV size
Associated with: PFO/ASD (causing cyanosis), WPW syndrome (15-20%)
Presentation: Wide spectrum from asymptomatic to neonatal heart failure
Physical exam: Cyanosis, prominent V wave (severe TR), holosystolic murmur ↑ with inspiration
CXR: Massive cardiomegaly, 'box-shaped' heart, clear lung fields
ECG: Tall P waves (RA enlargement), RBBB, possible WPW (delta wave)
Risk factor: Maternal lithium exposure during pregnancy
Treatment: Varies by severity—observation, tricuspid valve repair/replacement, or cardiac transplantation

questions.title: ALCAPA - Coronary Artery Anomaly
questions.subject: Pathology/Physiology
questions.topic: Anomalous Left Coronary Artery from Pulmonary Artery
questions.vignette: A 4-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department for irritability during feeding and profuse sweating. The parents report the infant has been less active over the past month and occasionally appears uncomfortable, drawing up the legs and crying inconsolably for 10-15 minutes. Physical examination reveals a pale, diaphoretic infant with tachypnea and tachycardia. The infant appears fatigued. A soft systolic murmur is heard at the apex with radiation to the axilla. The liver edge is palpable 3 cm below the right costal margin. Electrocardiogram shows deep Q waves in leads I and aVL with ST-segment depression and T-wave inversion in the lateral leads. Chest radiograph reveals cardiomegaly. Echocardiography demonstrates severe left ventricular dysfunction, mitral regurgitation, and bright echogenic areas in the anterolateral left ventricular wall.
questions.questionText: Which of the following is the most likely cause of this infant's condition?

answerChoices.text: Viral myocarditis causing diffuse ventricular dysfunction
Anomalous origin of the left coronary artery from the pulmonary artery
Idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy
Critical aortic stenosis with endocardial fibroelastosis
Kawasaki disease with coronary artery aneurysms

explanation.correct: This infant has anomalous left coronary artery from the pulmonary artery (ALCAPA), also known as Bland-White-Garland syndrome. In this rare congenital anomaly, the left coronary artery arises from the pulmonary artery instead of the aorta. Pathophysiology: In utero and immediately after birth, pulmonary artery pressure is elevated (near systemic), so the left coronary artery receives adequate flow. However, as PVR drops over the first weeks of life, pulmonary artery pressure falls dramatically, resulting in: (1) decreased perfusion pressure to the left coronary system → myocardial ischemia, (2) reversal of flow in the left coronary artery (blood flows from the RCA via collaterals TO the LCA and then into the low-pressure pulmonary artery—a 'coronary steal'), (3) chronic myocardial ischemia → anterolateral MI → LV dysfunction, mitral regurgitation (from papillary muscle dysfunction), and CHF. Presentation mimics angina in infants: irritability, sweating, inconsolable crying during feeds (when cardiac demand increases). ECG shows anterolateral MI pattern (deep Q waves in I and aVL). Echo shows bright myocardial areas (fibrosis/infarction) and severe LV dysfunction. This is a surgical emergency—the LCA must be reimplanted into the aorta.

incorrect.A: Viral myocarditis - Can cause acute heart failure and LV dysfunction in infants, but typically presents with sudden onset (days to weeks), often with preceding viral illness (fever, URI symptoms), and diffuse rather than regional wall motion abnormalities. The ECG would show diffuse ST-T changes, not the specific anterolateral MI pattern seen here. Echo findings of bright myocardium in a specific distribution (anterolateral) point to infarction, not diffuse myocarditis.
incorrect.C: Dilated cardiomyopathy - Idiopathic or familial dilated cardiomyopathy can present with heart failure in infancy but typically shows global ventricular dilation and diffuse hypokinesis without regional wall motion abnormalities. The ECG wouldn't show pathologic Q waves (indicating MI). The clinical presentation (episodes of irritability/pain during feeding) strongly suggests ischemia rather than primary muscle disease.
incorrect.D: Critical aortic stenosis - Presents in the first days/weeks of life (not months) with shock, poor perfusion, and ductal-dependent systemic circulation. Echo would show severe aortic valve stenosis and concentric LV hypertrophy with or without endocardial fibroelastosis. There would be no regional wall motion abnormalities or MI pattern on ECG—the LV dysfunction is global from pressure overload, not ischemia.
incorrect.E: Kawasaki disease - Causes coronary artery aneurysms and can lead to myocardial infarction, BUT Kawasaki disease presents with acute febrile illness (fever >5 days) plus specific mucocutaneous findings (conjunctivitis, rash, strawberry tongue, erythema of hands/feet, cervical lymphadenopathy). This infant has none of these features. Additionally, Kawasaki typically affects older infants/toddlers (peak 18-24 months), and coronary complications occur 2-4 weeks after fever onset, not as the presenting finding at 4 months.

questions.educationalObjective: Anomalous left coronary artery from the pulmonary artery (ALCAPA) presents at 2-4 months of age with myocardial ischemia and heart failure as PVR drops. Infants have angina-equivalent symptoms (irritability, sweating, crying with feeds), ECG shows anterolateral MI pattern, and echo demonstrates regional LV dysfunction with bright myocardial areas. Surgical reimplantation is required.
keyFacts: ALCAPA = left coronary artery arises from pulmonary artery (not aorta)
Pathophysiology: As PVR drops → ↓ PA pressure → ↓ LCA perfusion + coronary steal (blood flows LCA→PA)
Presentation: 2-4 months old, 'angina equivalent' (irritability, sweating, crying with feeds)
Mimics MI in infants: Anterolateral ischemia/infarction
Physical exam: Pallor, diaphoresis, tachycardia, CHF signs, mitral regurgitation murmur
ECG: Deep Q waves in I and aVL, ST depression, T-wave inversion (anterolateral MI pattern)
Echo: Regional wall motion abnormality (anterolateral), bright myocardium (infarction/fibrosis), severe LV dysfunction, MR
Chronic ischemia → LV failure, mitral regurgitation (papillary muscle dysfunction)
Natural history: 90% mortality by age 1 year without surgery
Treatment: Surgical reimplantation of LCA into aorta (emergency)
Mnemonic: ALCAPA = 'Angina-Like Crying And Poor Appetite'

questions.title: Hypoplastic Left Heart Syndrome - Ductal-Dependent Systemic Circulation
questions.subject: Pathology/Physiology
questions.vignette: A term newborn appears well immediately after birth but develops progressive lethargy, poor feeding, and mottled skin over the first 24 hours of life. By 36 hours, the infant is in extremis with profound metabolic acidosis, absent femoral pulses, and severe hypotension. Physical examination reveals a gray, cool infant with weak central pulses and absent peripheral pulses. A single loud S2 is heard without murmurs. Oxygen saturation is 85% in the right hand and 88% in the feet. Chest radiograph shows cardiomegaly with pulmonary edema. Echocardiography demonstrates severe hypoplasia of the left ventricle, mitral valve, and ascending aorta with aortic valve atresia. The patent ductus arteriosus is closing.
questions.questionText: Which of the following interventions would most likely stabilize this infant pending definitive surgical management?

answerChoices.text: Immediate atrial septostomy to improve mixing
Prostaglandin E1 infusion to maintain ductal patency
Supplemental oxygen to improve systemic oxygen delivery
Inotropic support with dopamine and milrinone
Emergent surgical closure of the patent ductus arteriosus

explanation.correct: This infant has hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS), the most severe form of left-sided obstructive lesion where the left ventricle, mitral valve, and ascending aorta are severely underdeveloped and the aortic valve is atretic (closed). In HLHS, systemic blood flow is ENTIRELY dependent on the right ventricle and patent ductus arteriosus: (1) the RV pumps blood to the pulmonary artery, (2) blood reaches the lungs normally, (3) oxygenated blood returns to the LA but cannot enter the hypoplastic LV, (4) blood crosses the atrial septum (R→L) to reach the RA and RV, (5) from the pulmonary artery, blood flows RETROGRADE through the PDA to supply the systemic circulation (including coronaries, which fill retrograde from the descending aorta). When the ductus begins to close (as it naturally does after birth), systemic perfusion ceases catastrophically → shock, acidosis, absent pulses, death. The IMMEDIATE intervention is prostaglandin E1 infusion to maintain ductal patency and restore systemic blood flow. This buys time for stabilization and surgical planning (Norwood procedure or cardiac transplant). Without PGE1, the infant will die within hours.

incorrect.A: Atrial septostomy - Atrial septostomy (balloon dilation of the atrial septum) is used to improve mixing when the atrial communication is restrictive. While HLHS does require adequate atrial-level shunting for survival, the PRIMARY problem in this decompensating infant is DUCTAL CLOSURE causing loss of systemic blood flow. Improving atrial mixing won't restore systemic perfusion if the duct is closed. PGE1 is the first priority.
incorrect.C: Supplemental oxygen - In HLHS, excessive oxygen is actually HARMFUL. High FiO2 causes pulmonary vasodilation, which increases pulmonary blood flow (Qp) at the expense of systemic blood flow (Qs). This worsens systemic perfusion. The goal in HLHS is BALANCED Qp:Qs (ideally 1:1), achieved by limiting oxygen (keep FiO2 ~21%, sats 75-85%) and sometimes adding CO2 to maintain PVR. Oxygen does not address the closed duct.
incorrect.D: Inotropes - While inotropic support may be used as an adjunct for shock, it does NOT address the fundamental problem: the duct is closing and there is no pathway for systemic blood flow. Dopamine and milrinone will not restore systemic perfusion if the ductus is closed. PGE1 must be given first to reopen the duct, then inotropes may help support cardiac output.
incorrect.E: Close the PDA - This would be FATAL. The PDA is the ONLY source of systemic blood flow in HLHS. Closing it would eliminate all systemic circulation and cause immediate death. The goal is to keep the ductus OPEN (with PGE1), not close it.

questions.educationalObjective: Hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS) is a ductal-dependent systemic circulation where the RV supplies both pulmonary and systemic (via PDA) blood flow. When the ductus begins to close, systemic perfusion fails catastrophically. Immediate prostaglandin E1 infusion is life-saving by maintaining ductal patency. Excessive oxygen is harmful as it increases pulmonary blood flow at the expense of systemic perfusion.
keyFacts: HLHS = hypoplastic LV, mitral valve, and ascending aorta + aortic atresia
Ductal-dependent SYSTEMIC circulation (RV supplies Qs via PDA)
Blood flow: RV → PA → (1) lungs and (2) PDA → systemic circulation (retrograde)
Coronaries fill retrograde from descending aorta via PDA
Presentation: Initially well → shock/collapse at 24-72 hours as ductus closes
Physical exam: Shock, absent peripheral pulses, single S2, no murmur
Oxygen paradox: High O2 → ↓ PVR → ↑ Qp → ↓ Qs → worse shock
Management: (1) PGE1 (life-saving), (2) limit FiO2 to 21%, (3) balance Qp:Qs
Definitive treatment: Staged surgical palliation (Norwood, Glenn, Fontan) or transplant
Without PGE1: Death within hours/days of ductal closure
Goal: Keep sats 75-85% with balanced Qp:Qs (not 100%)
